results.title: Our native shore
results.creator_credit: Andrew Rice, Esso Film Unit, British Information Services and Ronald Stark
results.brief_description: Shows the people whose lives and work are centred directly on the coastal areas of the British Isles and to whom the sea and ships are a part of their lives. Fisherman, coast guard, merchant seaman, life boat man, harbourmaster, shipwright, yachtsman, lighthouse keeper and a score of others move against a background rich in natural beauty and historical associations.

results.title: Our national heritage: the living pattern
results.creator_credit: Ralph Keene, Pilot Films, National Benzole and John Taylor
results.brief_description: Britain’s wildlife is the theme of this film. It shows most of the principal surviving wild animals in Britain, then the work of the Nature Conservancy in preserving them in nature reserves and elsewhere, and in carrying out ecological research.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ralph Keene, Pilot Films, National Benzole and John Taylor

results.title: Our living past
results.creator_credit: Andrew J. Helgeson, Austral Pacific Productions and Peter Thompson
results.brief_description: Deals with Australia’s heritage of historic places and buildings existing today, to be used and enjoyed by all. Describes Macquarie’s Old Government House, Sydney, The Rocks, Sydney; Royal Theatre, Hobart; Port Arthur, Tasmania; Windsor Hotel, Melbourne; the Lunatic Asylum, Perth; and many other places throughout Australia Photographed by Peter Leyden and Hans Heidrich. Sound by Kevin McLellan. Commentator, Tim Elliot.

results.title: Our land needs your help
results.creator_credit: Arthur Barr and Arthur Barr Productions
results.brief_description: Made to develop an awareness of our environmental problems. Follows a group of young people as they clean a polluted stream, check erosion, plant trees, and collect materials for recycling. Uses a blend of original songs, narration and natural sound.

results.title: Our inheritance from the past
results.brief_description: Explains, for American school children, how certain features of modern life have been inherited from the past. Instances the farm cultivator which developed from the ancient plough; the highway and its origin in Roman road-making; the wheel which was introduced in early history. The film also describes how knowledge is passed on either orally, in writing or in print.

results.title: Our inheritance from historic Greece
results.brief_description: Illustrates aspects of modern everyday life which can be traced back to that of the ancient Greeks. Aspects discussed are architecture, dress, ideas such as democracy, word derivations, electricity, zoology, mathematics and botany. Each element is depicted in its present-day use as well as its ancient Greek origin.

results.title: Our heritage
results.brief_description: Shows examples of carvings, statuary and sculpture to be found in religious temples and shrines in the Deccan area of Southern India. Hindu, Buddhist, Bravidiah and Muslem architecture are represented.

results.title: Our golden heritage
results.creator_credit: Film Partnership (Vic.) and Australian Dairy Board
results.brief_description: Traces the early methods of making butter, capturing something of the simplicity of Australia’s early history. From here the scene moves to the modern interior of a dairy factory showing buttermakers and packers at work. To conclude, some examples of the ways butter can be used in cooking are shown.

results.title: Our federal constitutional system
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Building Political Leadership”.
According to Dr. Ivan Hinderaker, the founders of the United States of America questioned whether they should control it. He explains how the American Constitution and the Bill of Rights came about, and claim that there are three main classifications of government: Dictatorship or Democracy? Unitary or Federal? Parliamentary or Presidential? Good use of graphics as an educational tool.
